awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: The Price of Property: An Economic and Spatial Analysis of American Indian Land Loss on the Western Frontier, 1880-1915
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This doctoral dissertation research in economics (DDRIE) project will study how the economic conditions, land rights, and water rights of American Indian tribes were influenced by western expansion. The evolution of American Indian development as a result of western expansion allows for the study of long-standing questions about institutional development in many ways---land and natural resource management during and since settlement, property rights enforcement, contract recognition, and corruption in public finance. This research is based on the construction of a new dataset based on highly disaggregated annual data that looks at individual land transfers over time and includes tribal characteristics, socio-economic data, land-use information, legal institutions, and details of financial arrangements between tribes and the U.S. government. This project will make available a new dataset of parcel-level data, collecting information held in the national archives and other sources that have been difficult to aggregate previously due to technological limitations. This project will broadly expand the accessibility of pivotal information regarding U.S. western settlements and the United States’ relationship with American Indian tribes.

The first section focuses on how land characteristics, socio-economic conditions, and public finance influenced American Indian reservation boundaries. The research team has have geocoded the transfers of individual parcels of land from Bureau of Land Management records and matched to reservation boundaries, data on land-price information, to historic reports from the Office of Indian Affairs, and to digitized U.S. – American Indian treaties. The land parcel data allows the researchers to analyze the checkerboarding of reservations, changes in patterns as new rules are introduced, the heterogeneity of experiences across tribes and reservations, and the impact of treaty and financial arrangements between the tribes and federal government. The second section then focuses on the political economy and legislative changes associated with land transfers – to examine the mechanisms of expropriation. The third section examines the impact of changes in and the uncertainty surrounding tribal water rights on western water use and quality. I use millions of observations of water pollution measurements from 1960 to the present to examine how the timing of lawsuits and specific settlements and rulings in these cases influenced water pollution patterns on reservations and outside reservations for surrounding waterways. The proposed project will thus enhance the current literature by using connecting new and existing historic information in novel ways to better understand the precursors and impacts of legal and economic institutions surrounding U.S. western settlement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the project was to better-understand how the economic conditions, land rights, and water rights of American Indian tribes were influenced by American western expansion. To support this broader goad, a major aim of this project was to build a foundational database from archived government reports on conditions (economic, demographic, environmental, financial, and social) relating to federal American Indian reservations during the pivotal period between 1880-1915. This time period encompasses rampant expansion in American western migration, coupled with large-scale, facilitating investment in infrastructure to support these shifts.

The task of building an informative dataset on the conditions American Indians faced on federally-recognized reservations and through treaties and contracts between tribes and the federal government was arduous and cumbersome. Yet this information is pivotally important for understanding how the extensive migration and extractive policies impacted American Indians who had already interacted with the federal government through treaty negotiations and land and resource disputes. Many records were kept at the time, but in disaggregated ways and in difficult-to-access formats. Sourcing, collecting, and linking such in a cohesive way across years, tribes and locations, had not been done outside of specific locations and time periods due to the time and resource investment necessary. This project, funding this effort, resulted in the construction of a novel dataset of highly disaggregated annual data on American-Indian reservations, including detail on economic activity, demographics, medical conditions and society; the fiduciary relationships between Native Nations and the U.S. federal government; and individual land transfers. This data will be linked spatially to geographic information on land settlement in order to study the granular and spatial story of western settlement, parcel by parcel, and its intersection with American Indian land loss.

Combining this spatial data with the archived information collected as part of this National Science Foundation project enables researchers to answer the following substantive questions about western settlement, and the development and impact of property rights to land and water:

1)     Did Federal Indian policies help or hinder tribes’ economic or health outcomes?

2)     Did factors such as resource availability or active economic industries on reservation accelerate or slow land encroachment?

3)     To what extent were the financial relationship between tribes and the federal government, outlaid in detailed contracts with liabilities owed and money held in government accounts tracked in archived reports, significant drivers of federal land policies on reservations?

4)     Did land transfers purposes recorded in the federal land disposal process have their intended consequences on land and population?

In addition to creating this detailed set of information and data for empirical research, this project also helped to support training and educating undergraduate students in databases creation, economic history, and in conducting empirical research. The provision of training and professional development opportunities was pivotal for this project. Over the course of the project, we hired nearly a dozen undergraduate students. Several students had never had the opportunity to work with data like this before, and several went on to pursue research-oriented careers or higher degrees as a result of their time on the project. Students learned important skills in data and time management, accuracy in data collection, research, fact-checking and organization.

 

Through this project, over 600 variables of data were collected, recorded in database form, and painstakingly linked for continuity across a thirty-five-year period, in five-year increments across all reported federal reservations in the annual reports. This is the first exhaustive set of data of this kind. All details of data have been meticulously coded for empirical analysis and continuity. Key outcomes include a workable dataset that can be deployed for empirical analysis, and an understanding of the depth and breadth of information that can be used in panel-data analysis for this topic area.

 

In terms of impact, the principal discipline of the project is economics, which relies on empirical evidence to unearth findings and knowledge about history and trends in human behavior given specific constraints, policies, geographic conditions, and other factors. It has been difficult to conduct empirical research on American Indian land loss during the time of American western settlement on a granular level, mostly because up until very recently, data (in granular form over wide geographic areas with variation in tribes, policies, and location) has been difficult to source. Recent advances in technology for digitizing and coding these variables has helped tremendously. The efforts of data collection for this project are based on those advances, and the end result will provide one of the first full sets of granular data on federal reservations and the contractual and fiduciary relationships between American Indian tribes and the federal government during this time period, which will allow for a much deeper understanding of the drivers and impacts of federal American Indian policies on American Indian tribes and the broader society during this time.
